title-group.article-title: Failure Mechanism of Crack on Oxide–Alloy Interface: An Elastic–Plastic Analysis

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30322-0405, USA
2Center for Reliable Energy Systems, Dublin, OH 43221, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: Hgzhou77@gmail.com

abstract.p: Spallation failure of oxide scale in high-temperature environment, usually occurring at the oxide–alloy interface, primarily originates from the interfacial defects such as cracks. At the same time, the substrate alloy usually experience plastic deformation during high-temperature oxidation process. In this study, we extend our previous work on stress-diffusion interaction in the oxidation of Fe–Cr alloys by including the inelastic deformation of alloys and use it to study the growth mechanism of a crack lying along oxide–alloy interface. The results predict that the plasticity of alloy helps to prevent the crack from growing. It is also found that faster diffusion of species will lead to higher level of interfacial failure driving force. Reduction of Cr ion diffusion in oxide by introduction of the reactive element in the alloy will help to prevent interfacial crack growth.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Growth of oxide scale on metallic alloys may cause significant mechanical stress in the scale layer. In return, such stress may affect the oxidation kinetics and may also lead to scale spallation or detachment (Noden et al., 1968; Rhines and Wolf, 1970; Stringer, 1970). Mechanisms of stress generation in the scale include heteroepitaxy (Pieraggi and Rapp, 1988), Pilling and Bedworth ratio (PBR) of conversion from metal into scale (Huntz, 1988; Kofstad, 1989), oxygen incorporation in substrate or reaction composition of oxygen and metal, non-stoichiometric vacancies concentration in the scale, etc. Among these, the PBR, i.e., the ratio of the oxide molar volume to that of the metal (Huntz, 1988; Kofstad, 1989), is believed to be primarily responsible for the generation of stresses during selective oxidation (Huntz, 1995), although oxygen incorporation in substrate or reaction composition of oxygen and metal may also introduce significant stresses in certain alloys.

Although mechanis+ms of oxidation-induced stresses have been studied extensively, very few attempts have been made to develop computational models to describe the oxidation-stress interaction process (Clarke, 2003; Krishnamurthy and Srolovitz, 2004; Limarga et al., 2004). Most of the existing models are based on the original concept of Rhines and Wolf (1970). Clarke (2003) considered the generation of lateral growth strain in response to the counter diffusion of cations and anions. By neglecting stress relaxation, he has shown that the lateral growth strain rate is proportional to the outward cation flux. Under a steady-state condition, Limarga et al. (2004) derived the average growth stress by assuming that the inward oxygen diffusion occurs along grain boundaries. A more general model describing the stress distribution in the oxide scale is presented by Krishnamurthy and Srolovitz (2004), in which they had formulated a continuum framework that predicts the oxide scale growth rate and the spatial distribution of stress and concentrations within the scale. The stresses affect internal oxidation by changing the free energy of the reaction and affect diffusion by modifying the chemical potential. This allows the authors to consider how the stress inhibits internal oxidation in a thermodynamically and kinetically consistent manner.

Cationic diffusion is one sequential process of alloy oxidation. Metal atoms’ ionization and diffusion process eventually lead to injection of vacancies into the alloy substrate. However, it has been observed that these vacancies are inconsistent with the strong adherence at alloy-oxide interface, in other words, the vacancies have to be annihilated by intrinsic dislocation climb into the metal (Pieraggi and Rapp, 1988). Interestingly, the dislocation has to return to the interface by a glide mechanism under the driving forces of strain energy minimization (Suo et al., 2003; El Kadiri et al., 2008), which conforms to the plastic deformation mechanism of alloys at moderate to high temperature, and hence provides local plastic strains.

Interfacial imperfections commonly exist between the oxide scales and the alloys during the oxidation process. The dissimilarity of material properties between alloys and oxides lead to complex interfacial fracture problems, especially for the ductile crack growth (Ohata et al., 2010). For the preexisting interfacial crack, an important issue is to determine its extending criteria. For elastic–plastic materials, the energy release rate can be estimated by the virtual crack closure technique (VCCT). A detailed review of VCCT can be found in the work of Krueger (2002). Cohesive zone models have also been increasingly employed for the description of failure behavior of interfacial flaw between dissimilar materials (Wu and Fang, 2009; Omiya and Kishimoto, 2010).

Most of the previous studies on oxide–alloy interfacial crack are related to the oxidation in thermal barrier coating (Yuan and Chen, 2003; Liu et al., 2004; Zhu et al., 2005). The major concern is the impact of thermal cycling on crack nucleation or the propagation of pre-existing interfacial crack. To date, only a few works have been conducted toward oxidation coupled approaches on oxide–alloy interfacial failure. Busso et al. (2001) proposed a coupled oxidation-constitutive approach and implemented it using finite element method to determine the interfacial and service parameters on the stress conditions required for crack nucleation. In the work of Caliez et al. (2002, 2003), the mechanical behavior of materials was coupled to a diffusion model to evaluate the stress filed responsible for interfacial crack initiation and propagation.

In this study, we focus on the study of oxide–alloy interface crack with consideration of stress-diffusion interaction during alloy oxidation process. Our previous work on stress-diffusion interaction model is extended by including inelastic deformation of alloy. A binary alloy (16% wt Cr–Fe) is used in this article as the model material. This model will be implemented in two-dimension (2D) using finite element method to study the growth mechanism of an interfacial crack lying along oxide–alloy interface after steady state has been reached. Finally, it will be seen from the derivation that the general approach presented here is applicable to a wide range of alloys.

sec.title: MODEL DESCRIPTION
sec.p: When writing the field quantities related to deformation such as strain and stress, it is often convenient to introduce the Lagrangian reference frame Xi (i = 1, 2, 3) and the Eulerian reference frame Xi (i = 1, 2, 3). We assume in this article that Xi coincide with xi initially at t = 0. The two coordinates are related by (1) where U(X,t) is the particle displacement of the particle X, while u(x,t) can be interpreted as the displacement of the particle instantaneously located at x.

sec.title: Kinematic Equations
sec.p: The total deformation gradient tensor F is related to the displacement vector U(X,t) through (2)

The eigentransformation due to compositional change is given by (3) where ηs is the coefficients of compositional expansion and Δcs is the deviation of molar fraction (cs) of species s from its stoichiometric composition (Swaminathan and Qu, 2007).
It then follows from the second of (2) that the transformation due to elastic–plastic deformation is (4)
Or it may be given in another form, i.e., the transformation due to elastic deformation is (5) where Fp is the transformation due to plastic deformation.
With substitution of (2) and (4), the green deformation tensors for stress free deformation and elasto-plastic deformation are separately obtained as (6)

For the oxidation problem considered here, there are several species in the scale layer 0≤x3≤h that may change their compositions. They are, respectively, Cr··· (s = Cr), O″ (s = O) and Cr2O3 (s = p), due to the formation of oxide from Cr··· and O″. For Cr2O3, we have ηp=(2+3)/3=5/3, while ηCr··· and ηO can be measured experimentally or computed using molecular dynamic simulations (Swaminathan and Qu, 2009). In the metal (x3<0), chromium atom (s = Cr(a)) is the only independent diffusible species.
We assume that the total strain is the sum of elastic strains, inelastic strains, and strains due to compositional change, i.e., (7) or the elastic strains are given as (8)

sec.title: Kinetic Equations
sec.p: The mechanical stresses in both the oxide scale and the metal substrate must satisfy the equilibrium equations. In terms of the first-Piola–Kirchhoff stress tensor, the equilibrium equations can be written as (9) where the first-gradient operator is with respect to the Lagrangian coordinates X and the second one is with respect to the spatial coordinates x, as indicated by the subscript. Making use of the Hooke’s law, one can express the first-Piola–Kirchhoff stress tensor in term of the deformation gradients, (10) where C is the elastic stiffness tensor. In this article, it is assumed that C is independent of Δcs.

In the alloy part, when plastic deformation occurs, the rate of deformation can be given by the flow rule, i.e., (11) or in the form of deformation gradient (12) where λ· is a scalar multiplier and S the deviatoric stress tensor.

sec.title: Stress-dependent Chemical Potential
sec.p: Strictly speaking, electrochemical potentials should be used for the oxidation process. However, if local electroneutrality is assumed (as done here), the diffusion process can be described using the chemical potential alone (Swaminathan et al., 2007). For most insulating and semi-conducting ceramics, local electroneutrality is an excellent assumption throughout the film, except for thin surface layers of a few nanometers (Dechamps and Barbier, 1991; Krishnamurthy and Srolovitz, 2003). The stress-dependent chemical potential for a species s in ionic solids has been derived in Swaminathan et al. (2007), (13) where μs0 is the chemical potential of species s at some reference state, R and T the universal gas constant and temperature, respectively, Vsm the molar volume of species s in its nature (stress-free stoichiometric state). The last term in (13) is the stress-dependent part of the chemical potential derived in Swaminathan et al. (2007) and El Kadiri et al. (2008). If one assumes that the elastic stiffness tensor is independent of concentration, then τs reduces to (14) where Jc=‖Fc‖ is the Jacobian of the deformation gradient tensor and ws(Cpe) the partial derivative strain energy density with respect to the species concentration, i.e., (15) and the Eshelby stress tensor is in the form of El Kadiri et al. (2008) (16) where w0(CF) is the strain energy density in stress-free state and σ~ the second-Piola–Kirchhoff stress tensor.

sec.title: 2D IMPLEMENTATION ON SMALL-SCALE YIELDING EXAMPLE
sec.p: To illustrate the utility of the model formulated above and to reveal certain fundamental features of the model predictions, we present a 2D numerical example in this section. The inelasticity of the substrate alloy is considered in two cases. The inelasticity of the substrate alloy is assumed to be deformation plasticity. Furthermore, since the inelastic behaviors accommodate the deformation due to non-stoichiometry and materials are confined in fixed areas, the plastic deformations are assumed to be small scale yielding.

sec.title: Alloy-oxide Model with Isotropic Deformation Plasticity in Alloy
sec.p:
Figure 1 illustrates the geometry of a 2D model of an alloy carrying a Cr2O3 layer at its top surface. A pre-existing crack lies along the oxide–alloy interface. The 2D model has an x3 thickness that is very large in comparison with the dimensions in the other two directions. This figure is for illustration purpose only and is not to scale. In this case study, we assume that all the material properties are independent of the ion concentration. Also, the scale layer are assumed to be linear elastic and isotropic solids with E1 and ν1 being the elastic constants, and the metal substrate are assumed to be elastic–plastic and isotropic solids with E2 and ν2 being the elastic constants. The plastic constants will be given in later derivation. All the elastic and plastic constants are assumed to be independent of the defect concentration for case of the dilute concentration. Figure 1.
Schematic of the alloy-oxide structure with a interfacial crack (not to scale).

Since failure-inducing defects such as voiding and spallation usually take place after relatively long period of oxidation, we assume that a steady state of oxidation has been reached. So, we only focus on steady-state oxidation in this study. In this case, the interfacial failure is of our most interests other than the oxide kinetics. Since the surface growth of oxide has few effects on the interfacial crack growth driving force, we then assume a relatively thick scale and ignore the scale growth afterward. Based on this assumption, it is different from previous studies that the steady state in this case is time independence.

sec.title: Stress-dependent Chemical Potential
sec.p: In 2D case, the chemical potential that governs diffusion can be obtained from Equation (13). When species s being the chromium atom, chemical potential (17) where μCr(a)0 is the chemical potential of chromium atom at reference state, VCr(a) m the molar volume of substrate alloy in its natural (stress-free stoichiometric) state. The stress-dependent part of the chemical potential in Equation (17) for small strain deformation is in the form of (18) where εijp is the plastic strain, the elastic strain tensor [εe] (or εije) and elastic constant tensor will be given in the following section.
The chemical potentials of chromium ion and oxygen ion in oxide are also defined by (13) with the stress dependent part given as (19)
In Equations (18) and (19), the elastic constants (20) with i = 1 or 2 represents alloy or oxide.

sec.title: Governing Equations in 2D
sec.p: From Zhouet al. (2010), deformation and defect concentration throughout the oxide scale layer and alloy substrate can be solved from the corresponding governing partial differential equations with proper continuity conditions. For the 2D model in this study, the equilibrium equations (21) have to be satisfied both in the oxide and in the alloy substrate.
The non-zero elastic strain components in oxide scale are given as (22)
The corresponding constitutive relations in scale are given as (23)
In the substrate alloy, relationship (8) leads to (24) and the corresponding stress in substrate ally are obtained as (25) where the deviatoric stresses (26)

In Equations (23)–(25), E is Young’s modulus, ν the Poisson’s ratio, α the yield offset, σ0 the yield stress in one-direction tensile load, n the plastic hardening exponent, q the effective stress with the form of (27)

The mass continuity equations for Cr and O ions in the oxide scale are given as (28) where DCr and DO are the diffusivity of chromium and oxygen ions in oxide. And for Cr atoms in the alloy substrate (29) where DCr(a) is the diffusivity of chromium atom in Fe–Cr alloy.
With the chemical reaction equilibrium assumption, we have (30) in the oxide scale.

In addition to the governing equations above, interface conditions need to be specified. In the structure shown in Figure 1, there are two interfaces, the metal-scale interface and the scale-air interface. At these interfaces, the following conditions must be satisfied: (1) mass flux continuity of each species, (2) continuity of chemical potential of each species for adsorption and ionization reaction, respectively, (3) continuity of displacement, and (4) continuity of traction. These conditions are described below.

sec.title: Metal-Scale Interface (x2=0)
sec.p: The metal-scale interface is divided into two portions: the perfect portion and the crack portion. For the former interface, ionization of Cr atoms is assumed to be an equilibrium process. Thus, continuity of chemical potentials must hold between Cr ions and Cr atoms, i.e., (31)
Conservation of mass for Cr across the interface leads to (32)
Furthermore, traction continuity is automatically satisfied by the choice of stress components, and the continuity of displacement leads to (33)
For the crack portion, corresponding continuity of Cr chemical potentials leads to:alloy side (34) oxide side (35) and conservation of mass for Cr is:alloy side (36) oxide side (37)
At both surfaces of the crack, traction free condition is automatically satisfied by the choice of stress components.
Finally, per the assumption that no O can cross the interface for both portions, i.e., (38)

sec.title: At the Scale-Air Interface (x2=h)
sec.p: At the scale-air interface, equilibrium condition is assumed for ionization of oxygen (in the air), i.e., (39)
Note that unlike the previous study, h is known a priori in this case. In addition, a fixed value boundary condition is applied on Cr ions at the surface, i.e., (40)

Furthermore, it is assumed that, in comparison with the stresses in the scale layer, the atmosphere pressure is negligible in typical applications. Thus, the scale-air interface can be viewed as a traction free surface which is satisfied by the choice of the stress components.
Inside the alloy far from the interface, cCr(a)=C as x2→-∞. Additionally, periodic boundaries are applied at the left (x1=-w2) and right (x1=w2) hand side of the 2D model, i.e., (41)

sec.title: Implementation Description
sec.p:
The 2D diffusion-stress coupling model for steady-state oxidation of a binary alloy was implemented by finite element method in the commercial software ABAQUS with a user defined element subroutine. Emphasis was put on the crack extension driven forces and failure. As shown in Figure 1, a binary alloy carrying a layer of oxide on it top with a crack lying along the scale-alloying interface is considered in this implementation. Continuity Equations (28), (29) and equilibrium Equation (21) together with corresponding boundaries are solved simultaneously to obtain u1, u2, cCr, cO and cCr(a). Oxygen partial pressure is set to be 0.3 atm at the air-oxide interface. Finally, in this simulation, all the materials (alloy, oxide) are assumed to be homogeneous and isotropic. All material properties used in this finite element implementation are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Material properties of Cr–Fe alloy and its oxide.
Chromium properties Symbol Value
Chemical expansion coefficient ηCr 0.05
ηO 0.02
ηp 5/3
Diffusivity of chromium ion DCr 5.8 × 10−13 cm2/s
Diffusivity of oxygen ion DO 3.0 × 10−15 cm2/s
Temperature T 1073 K
Young’s modulus E1 250 GPa
Poisson’s coefficient ν1 0.27
Molar volume Vmp 2.92 × 10−5 m3/mol
16% (wt) Cr–Fe alloy properties Symbol Value
Chemical expansion coefficient ηCr(a) 0.05
Diffusivity of chromium atom DCr(a) 2.86 × 10−15 cm2/s
Young’s modulus E2 162.3 GPa
Poisson’s coefficient ν2 0.29
Yield offset α 0.93
Yield stress in one direction tensile load σ0 195 MPa
The plastic hardening exponent N 9.14

sec.title: Results and Discussions
sec.p:
The simulation is first carried out on the oxide scale bucking instability for validation. Under certain equi-biaxial compressive in-plane stress σ11 = σ33 = - σ c, the oxide scale above the interfacial scale will bulk up. The analytical solution for this bucking instability has been obtained by Hutchinson and Suo (1992). The classical bucking stress of a clamped-clamped wide plate is solved as the critical bucking stress, which is in the form of (42) where a is the half crack length. To compromise with the analytical solution, the finite element analysis is applied to a bimaterial interfacial crack problem with ignoring plastic deformation in alloy. The relation between σc and h/a from finite element solution is plotted in Figure 2 along with the analytical relation (42). The solutions have fairly good agreement with each other, especially at the period that h/a≤0.1. In this study, the half crack length a used in this simulation is 20 µm. Therefore, as long as the scale is not much thicker than 2 µm, which is the typical steady-state scale thickness, the finite element solution is valid. For h/a>>0.1, the small h/a assumption of the analytical solution is violated, hence solution (42) may not be inappropriate. Figure 2.
Oxide scale bucking instability.

In previous works (Zhou et al., 2010), we have analyzed the stress distribution in oxide scale and alloy, which gives us a general view of possible failure mechanism as well as critical locations. High level of normal tensile stress has been predicted at oxide–alloy interface, which is consistent with the experimental observation. However, understanding of the evolution of defects is still needed and necessary, especially the parameters that affect the failure driving force.

The energy release rate G, defined as energy dissipated during fracture, is considered as the crack growth driving force in this study. Since the loading in the model is only due to the volume change of oxide and alloy with no external work sources, the energy release rate can be evaluated by the VCCT. For a model of elastic–plastic Cr–Fe alloy carrying a scale of thickness h = 1 µm, with half crack a = 20 µm, the energy release rate is obtained as 8.9 J/m2.

For the growth of an interfacial crack, it is necessary to examine whether this crack experiences a stable crack growth or under stable fracture process. Figure 3 shows that when the oxide scale are with the same thickness, the variation of energy release rate along with the crack growth for doped and undoped Fe–Cr alloys at 1073 K. Due to symmetry, the energy release rates of the left and the right ends are almost identical, which could be also observed in later results. As seen, the energy release rates of both the left and the right cracks increase with the growth of crack. This means that for any given crack with certain crack length, if the energy release rate is initially smaller than the critical value Gc, the crack rests. Figure 3.
Energy release rate change with half crack length at the same oxide scale thickness.

As discussed before in Zhou et al. (2010), reactive element dopant such as Yttrium has important effect on oxide scale protection. One of the explanations is that the dopant would help to reduce the failure driving force. However, it draws immediate attention that in Figure 3, the energy release rate obtained from doped alloy is about three times of that from undoped alloy. This seems to be different from intuition because the result predicts that, under the same conditions, the oxide on doped alloy tends to spall off easily. The reason is that the oxide scales on both alloys are assumed to be the same. Comparing the oxidation kinetics of doped and undoped alloys, we can find that it takes much longer time for the doped alloy to form the same thickness of oxide as does the undoped alloy. This means that in reality the doped alloy experiences much longer time of oxidation, and therefore, it shows higher tendency for crack growth. To demonstrate the reactive element effect on fracture driving force G, it is better for us to compare the results at the situation that the alloys experiences oxidation for the same time. Since all the simulations are carried out with time independence, a compromise which we call ‘same time rule’ is made. From the oxidation kinetics in Zhou et al. (2010), a 1.5-µm oxide scale is formed on pure alloy after 500 h of oxidation. While for doped alloy, a 0.8-µm oxide scale is predicted (Zhou et al., 2010) after the same time of oxidation. We then obtained the G–a relation with h = 1.5 µm for pure alloy and h = 0.8 µm for doped alloy, which is plotted Figure 4. Now, we can see that after the same time oxidation, oxide-doped alloys model supplies less energy driven force for spallation. Figure 4.
Energy release rate change with half crack length at the same oxidation time.

The previous studies have shown that not only the crack length can affect the energy release rate of the interfacial crack but also the oxide scale thickness may have its impact. Figure 5 shows the relation between the energy release rate of the interfacial crack and the oxide scale thickness. Accompanying the growth of scale thickness, the energy release rate increases. Hence, we can say that in the oxidation process, an existing crack defect will subject to an increasing crack-extension driving force when the oxide scale keeps growing. Comparison in Figure 5 shows that doped alloy is with higher energy release rate than the one with the undoped alloy at the same oxide scale level, which is consistent with the discussion given in Figure 3. Furthermore, the energy release rate obtained from doped alloy is more sensitive to the change of scale thickness. This may be due to the strain energy density in the oxide-doped alloy model is greater than that in the oxide-pure alloy model. Hence, the application of VCCT realizes in the variation of strain energy per unit extension area for crack between oxide and doped alloy is higher than that for crack between oxide and pure alloy. Figure 5.
Energy release rate change with oxide scale thickness.

For a specific alloy, the thickness of its oxide scale after oxidation increase with the oxidation time; while for different alloys, their oxide thicknesses after the same time of oxidation vary due to different rates of ionic diffusion. Impacts of diffusivities on oxidation kinetics may eventually realize in the effects on interfacial crack growth driving force. Figure 6 gives the relation between energy release rate and the overall diffusivity of Cr ions in oxide scale at 1073 K. The variation of diffusivity can be originated from the variation of dopant content in alloy, which has been discussed in Zhou et al. (2010). The energy release rate G is calculated based on the ‘same time’ rule, i.e., for each diffusivity, we obtain the oxide scale thickness (Figure 7) from the kinetics calculation of 500 h of oxidation and then use this scale thickness in finite element analysis for its corresponding energy release rate. Results in Figure 6 show that, under the same conditions, a crack with pure elastic alloy substrate has more failure driving force than the one with elastic–plastic alloy substrate, i.e., the plasticity of alloys help prevent the crack from growing. For both curves in Figure 6, a trend of slope increasing is observed. This means that after same time period of oxidation, faster diffusion of species will lead to higher level of interfacial failure driving force. Observations on stress distribution in oxide and alloy structure have further proved this. Distribution of σ11 in oxide scale with elastic alloy, elastic–plastic alloy, and elastic–plastic doped alloy are plotted in Figure 8(a)–(c), respectively. Comparison between Figure 8(a) and (b) illustrate that plasticity helps to reduce the maximum tensile and compressive stresses. Further reduction of maximum stress magnitude can be found in Figure 8(c), i.e., the additive dopants could lead to lower stress generation and hence lower failure driven. This is consistent with the trend predicted in Figure 6. The stress σ22, generated as the consequence of in plane stress and chemical origins, shows a similar decreasing trend, especially for σ22 around crack tip. The plasticity trims down a huge magnitude of interfacial tensile stresses from those induced in the elastic case (Figure 9). Figure 6.
Energy release rate change with diffusivity. Figure 7.
Corresponding oxide scale thickness for diffusivity of Cr in oxide. Figure 8.
Distribution of σ11 when alloy is: (a) elastic, (b) elastic–plastic, and (c) elastic– plastic with yttrium dopant. Figure 9.
Distribution of σ22 when alloy is (a) elastic, (b) elastic–plastic, and (c) elastic–plastic with yttrium dopant.

Asymptotic stress field around the crack tip has also been obtained for possible failure mode analysis. The measure of mode mixity ψ with a reference length L from the crack tip is given as (Hutchinson and Suo, 1992) (43) where K1 and K2 are the stress intensity factors, L a reference length, and i=-1.
When the distance from crack tip along interface is L, the mode mixity is reduced to (44)
Due to the freedom in choice of L, the mode mixity at any radius r along the interface is then obtained as (45)

Following Bose et al. (1999), we set the reference length L to be the plastic zone size, which is given as (46) where Kel is the magnitude of the complex stress intensity factor and τ0 the alloy yield stress in shear.

Figure 10(a) gives the mode of mixity along the oxide–alloy interface in front of the crack tips. The modes of mixity for both tips are very close to mode II with the values are close to 90° and −90°, respectively. The mixed mode curve for right tip of the crack is re-plotted in Figure 10(b) for more details. Both of these figures shows that shear stresses have stronger effect along the alloy-scale interface and this effect decreases a little along with the increase of distance from crack tip. This can be accounted for by the trend of volume expansion of scale layer and the trend of volume contraction of the alloy substrate. Figure 10.
Mode of mixity along: (a) oxide–alloy interface and (b) oxide–alloy interface in front of the right tip of the crack.

The angular variations of normalized stresses σ12/σmax and σ22/σmax are obtained and plotted in Figure 11, where σmax is the maximum magnitude of the stresses. In this study, σmax=233 MPa. Due to the symmetry of the crack about x1 = 0, the normal stresses σ22 around the two tips are almost identical while the shear stresses are anti-symmetric to each other. The highest shear stress for both tips occurs at θ=0∘ For the normal stresses, the highest value is reached at θ≈90∘, which is in the elastic oxide scale right above the crack tip; besides, only tensile stress occurs in the oxide scale. In the elastic–plastic alloy part, the alloys first experience a tensile stress, while it may have reached the yield stress of the alloy. Then, when the tensile stress relax at θ≈-90∘, which is the area behind the crack, the compressive normal stresses occurs as the consequence of yielding and causes a possible crack tip closure. Figure 11.
Angular variation of normalized stresses near the: (a) right tip of a center crack and (b) left tip of a center crack.

sec.title: SUMMARY
sec.p: In this article, a continuum thermodynamics model is developed to include alloy inelastic behavior into stress-diffusion interaction during oxidation of Cr–Fe alloys. The chemical potential is related with not only the concentration of species and elastic deformation, but also inelastic deformation. This gives a fully coupled relation between the chemical reaction and mechanical stress, namely not only oxidation induces stress, but in return stress also affects the rate of oxidation by changing the elastic–plastic deformation. As an example, this model has been implemented in 2D using finite element method to study the growth mechanism of an interfacial crack along oxide–alloy interface after steady state has been reached. The presented results provide clear insight of how plastic deformation of alloy affects the stresses distribution around the crack tip and crack growth driving force. It is also found that reactive element effect on reducing ionic diffusion and the resultant slow oxidation kinetics help to rest the interfacial crack. Finally, it should be pointed out that, although it is developed based on a Cr–Fe alloy, the present model can be easily extended to many different types of binary alloys.

fn.p: Figures 8 and 9 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com
